title: Ahoy, and thanks for visiting!
text:
Ahoy, and thanks for visiting!
I am a PhD student, chronic problem-solver, question-asker, and out-of-doors enthusiast. I am most interested in answering questions related to global marine sustainability and the persistence of species, particularly surrounding the efficacy of current ocean management in the face of climate threats. PhD’s grant many wonderful opportunities that lead to realisations, the most notable among mine being a love for data visualisation, teaching, and finding solutions that are robust to the passage of time.
With an expected graduation date of September 2025, I am searching for post-doc opportunities around the world within the field of quantitative marine ecology. I am particularly interested in projects with a focus on using climate projections and metrics to understand the possible responses of marine biodiversity to mid- and long-term climate threats, and to use this to inform the management of resources.

Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

The History of the War of the Ring

I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Test blog
text:
Quarto ‘quick and dirty’ or {Golem} for longevity and complexity?
As expected in an open-source programming language, the app-making landscape in R seems to be in constant flux. Something newish that I’ve been finding useful lately is using Quarto’s ‘Dashboards with Shiny for R’ feature.
Quarto is very similar to Rmarkdown, but has a few additional features. One of them is the ability to embed R {shiny} apps. So you end up writing your app like you would a markdown doc - the context, ui, and server are all code chunks, and the text around those code chunks set’s up the UI. For example, normally in markdown we use # to delineate and navigate headers; in Quarto Shiny Dashboards, # are used to delineate pages, tab panels, etc.
I’ve found it’s great for proto-typing simple apps - you can get something up and running very quickly in Quarto’s ‘Dashboards with Shiny for R’. However, I think it could get unwieldy when you start building complex apps with modules etc. In that case, developing your {shiny} app as an R package with {golem} might be a better option. {golem} provides a great framework for engineering production grade shiny apps that are complex and can be easily maintained in the long-term.
I ended up turning the prototype app I built in Quarto’s ‘Dashboards with Shiny for R’ into an R package with {golem}. It took much longer than I expected, but much of that time was learning about R package development (which I had never done before) and {golem}.
In the end I think it was worth the extra time and effort streamline as an R package. But if you want to compare for yourself, find the protoype Quarto dashboard shiny here and the {golem} R package version here.
Curious to hear others’ experiences though - please get in touch.

title: Current projects
text:
PhD chapters (University of the Sunshine Coast, QLD, Australia)


Future ocean climate and implications for Australia’s marine protected areas (in press)


 Climate change is a pervasive global threat to people and nature. In the oceans, there is a suite of climate impacts, including chronic stressors such as warming, acidification, deoxygenation, and acute stressors such as marine heatwaves. The primary approach for conserving marine biodiversity is the use of protected areas, which can manage local stressors such as fishing, shipping and mining, but offer little protection from climate change if they are not designed around areas of least change. Here we use climate projections from a suite of CMIP6 Earth System Models to assess the exposure to climate change of waters within the Australian EEZ, and implications for the protected area network. We find that marine ecosystems will experience conditions outside their historical range for all scenarios that exceed 2°C warming this century, resulting in a disappearance of climate refugia – areas of slowest change – by 2040. The loss of climate refugia is likely to lead to poor biodiversity outcomes, including movement of biodiversity outside protected area boundaries. However, we find some capacity for the re-emergence of refugia in the latter half of the century under stronger mitigation scenarios. Moreover, we find that the placement of Australian marine protected areas (MPAs) in terms of climate change is no better than random. The MPA network has a similar exposure to warming, acidification, deoxygenation and marine heatwaves than areas outside, implying limited consideration of climate change in protected area design. Our findings on the changes in chronic stressors, extreme events and climate refugia could be used to expand or redesign the current network to increase climate resilience to climate change.

title: Photography
text: As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.
